title: Why the players of League are most notably upset at the developers
body:
Hey there, I decided to make this thread as an explanation (in my opinion) as to why players are so upset right now, and even going to the lengths of calling on the firing of developers (not just Certainlyt, but in general)

The whole fiasco has very deep roots through the past few years, likely dating back to Season 5. "Power Creep" and "Mobility Creep" are common terms thrown out by players in frustration, and understandably so. I like to compare this creep to that of slowly heating up the water in a shower, bath, etc. It changes so slowly that you don't notice it at all until you look back (or change it back) to what it was a good while ago. Players looking back see that over time the game has added so much power creep that we have the mess we see today.

The blame cast on the developers isn't just the blind rage you see in soloq, there has been a lot of constructive criticism for awhile now. 

The first big upset to the community was the midseason patch for S7, including big updates to some tanks. Riot had their heart in the right place and noticeably put effort into the redesigns, however in many peoples' view, it was a flop. This can be blamed on the toxic jungle meta that spawned from it. When this occurred, it was a hot topic for discussion. People spouted the ugly term "Tank Meta" about for a good while (which I will probably cover in a whole separate post) and actively suggested solutions to the problem. Some good, some bad. Some wanted reverts, others wanted numbers tweaks, and few even suggested another update. At this point NOT many people were very upset at the developers at all, especially since the start of season 7, after the fixes to adc (and killing our meme), was quite smooth. The real screwup was when Riot actively IGNORED or REFUSED all of the criticism it took from the players.

The next big thing in season 7 would have to be the ardent meta. I myself blame this meta (as a mid lane mage main) for screwing with my ranked matches, seeing as my climb from Silver V to Gold IV, which took place in a matter of weeks, abruptly stopped and I simply couldn't win anymore without a good bot lane. The winrate on my main, Veigar, dropped from a whopping 74% to 66% by the end of the season (and that is over around 70 games of veigar in S7), and winrate overall dropped from around 65% to 56%. This thing made A LOT of people angry. Not because of the actual ardent meta existing in the first place, but because it wasn't fixed at all until about 2 patches before preseason. Riot abused the "muh worlds" excuse way too much and we had pretty much the latter half of the summer and early fall in absolute misery. Standalone this isn't a real killer to the community, but factoring in the tank jungle meta before, and what happened after, it really is.

You see, the reason people kept playing during the ardent meta was because of one promise from the developers: "Preseason will fix most of the problems with the game." When preseason came around, the players were excited to change from the trash meta they had before. Players saw a transition  from a teamfight where the adc can literally tank your whole team from all the heals/shields/peel they get, to now absolute kill lanes and players being wiped in seconds. Theoretically, this would be nice, but it wasn't. **This is because the added damage was not properly set up by any other balance changes.** Think about it. Did mages and assassins become super viable again like previous seasons, or instead did ADCs start picking up full damage + crit and start outputting Burst Per Second that could wipe everyone 1v5? Did the high amount kills around other ever-present gold income from previous metas, like first turret gold, make games way more snowbally? It sure did.

At this point the players' tempers were stretched thin. This was a problem and we looked upon one last promise from Riot: "Preseason may be unbalanced so we will try to fix it." Patch 7.24b was an INCREDIBLE let down. Riot promised changes to top lane, which they did test extensively in the PBE, but ended up just rolling them back. While this in itself isn't a bad move, Riot neglected to replace those changes before the patch dropped. Players now had to endure for the holidays (one of the best times for gaming) with a terribly unbalanced game while Rioters were not even working.

That was the last straw. The entire time players had been offering good ideas and constructive criticism. There are still a plethora of threads, articles, and videos about how the game could be improved, but Riot never listened. On top of that, they actively failed to follow through with their promises of actual game balance, all the while CertainlyT would develop a second Yasuo.

This is the point where players start calling for the balance team to be fired. I agree, this is absolutely unacceptable, and is the first time since midseason 6 that I am actively trying to avoid playing league, even in the holiday season. We, the players have gone through a hell of a terrible ride over the past **5 months or so,** and honestly have all rights to start calling out the team for their blatant neglect.

TLDR: Riot hasn't listened to the playerbase over a multitude of patches spanning about 5 months. While their fuckups in balance weren't that bad, the fact that they didn't fix them at all, or until much later, made people upset enough to call on the firing of the balance team.

This is an interesting philosophical question that comes up all the time when I'm ingame and subjected to some unsavory comments about champion picks. As a member of the playtest team, I *should* be playing what's meta in my opinion. If I have to work on a champion ticket or another balance change, I'd rather be informed than go in dry. What's meta these days is often strongest (or close to it), as LoL is in a spot now where looking at amazing community-driven websites allows people to figure out what's OP quite quickly. Do I enjoy playing Malzahar? Hell no (personally I get bored of him easily). But, if we were to nerf him at some point, I would like to be able to contribute towards Live Gameplay's understanding of what they could change with his tuning, and that's done best by a combination of both playing the character and doing my own research/numbers sweeps.

> As a member of the playtest team, I should be playing what's meta in my opinion. 

That's the philosophy that is leaving underplayed champions in the dust. You focus on the META champions and ignore long forgotten champions which might counter those picks in the first place. Some of the underplayed champions might be a safety valve against the META champions becoming overbearing if they were given some love. Also playing champions who are countered by the META champion might give the insight necessary to distinguish when and why the META champion is overbearing in their matchups while giving greater insights into the game as a whole instead of just on the individual champion. 

Maybe the playtesters should try for a variety of experiences to get insights from different angles instead of spamming a small handful of the strong champions limiting their ability to comment on the game as a whole. Just a dissenting opinion though.

> Maybe the playtesters should try for a variety of experiences to get insights from different angles instead of spamming a small handful of the strong champions limiting their ability to comment on the game as a whole. Just a dissenting opinion though.

We generally have pretty good coverage on champions in terms of understanding them. Most players on my team have played the game in high elo for a loooong time (I've played since January of 2010). That said, there is a certain amount of game knowledge filtering that good players will do to avoid wasting time. I don't think playing 10 Volibear/nunu games is necessary to determine that they're not  hidden counters to Malzahar.

> I don't think playing 10 Volibear/nunu games is necessary to determine that they're not hidden counters to Malzahar. 

Of course not, playing 10 games of all 139 champions is unreasonable, and its also not what i said. 

> As a member of the playtest team, I should be playing what's meta in my opinion.

I just mean that there needs to be a balance of what is played, instead of focusing on what is meta as you suggest. If balance and playtesting was focused not on rotating the meta of what is currently strong, but on a vision of what a balanced game would look like i think we would all be in a better spot. 

If Malz is over-performing (to piggyback off your example) questions need to be asked about why his counters aren't able to do their jobs against him. Maybe Malz is just plain too strong, maybe his kit is covering his own weaknesses too well, maybe his counters are just too weak overall, or maybe his counters strengths are being mitigated in unintended ways that have nothing to do with Malz. Like, maybe his counters ([Swain](http://www.op.gg/champion/malzahar/statistics/mid),  [Karthus](http://www.op.gg/champion/malzahar/statistics/mid), [Anivia](http://www.op.gg/champion/malzahar/statistics/mid)), [Gangplank](http://lolcounter.com/champions/malzahar), [Syndra](http://lolcounter.com/champions/malzahar), [Galio](http://lolcounter.com/champions/malzahar), to list counters that i can source for credibility...\) are mostly late game scaling champions in a fast meta, and game pacing issues are the underlying reason for Malz's strength. That's the kind of insight that you probably won't get by spamming Malz.

EDIT: -----

Also on the flip side Malz counters [early game snowballing champions](http://lolcounter.com/champions/malzahar) that are popular in the fast meta and so they can not snowball against him because they are countered, while also not being able to transition into the mid/late game because they were unable to get the lead that their champion needs to function. Some of that is just how his counter matchups work, but shorter games mean there is less time for those early game champions to find ways to eek out an advantage somewhere other than early lane. 

Malz just happens to serve as a microcosm of why game pacing is a problem right now, and similar strengths and weaknesses continue to pop up through the game in other lanes as well. We are seemingly left with a choice between homogenizing power curves of champions somewhat to compensate for shortening game lengths, increasing game lengths back to what they were a few years ago, or [leaving these problems to continue cropping up.](http://izquotes.com/quotes-pictures/quote-failure-is-always-an-option-adam-savage-163193.jpg) In any case, [Happy New Year, and Cheers Mate!](http://m.memegen.com/kw2m1r.jpg)

i didn't mean to assume you meant spam every character, was just using that as an example of why stressing off-meta characters isn't always the go-to strategy as it is both time consuming and often not worth it.

And how much does that approach lead to bias towards the default? Out of sight, out of mind for the non-meta, less popular champs.

Live Gameplay generally spearheads the approach to working on underutilized/underpicked champions. If we have tickets upcoming for underplayed champions, the first thing my team does is assign someone to start spamming games on it to understand the character.  I'm just saying that balance team members playing OP stuff in solo queue is not some conspiracy to gain elo -- it's often to understand the champion for further work.

Something i'd actually like to know to get behind what is happening behind the scenes if you don't mind: Does the balance team just do their thing  and you then have to find out if these changes were good, healthy whatever or do you go to the balance team and say: yo i've played some X would be nice if you could do Y or Z to X because of A and B  reason? 
Or is it some inbetween?

It's closer to in between. Usually the TL;DR workflow (meaning there is much more but it's complex to describe all the various timings due to how our patch dev cycle works) is:

1) Live Gameplay has their sprint planning, which is when they discuss as a team what they want to work on (this can be underplayed characters, OP characters, whatever!)  
2) Live Gameplay may or may not sync up with the playtesters for whatever respective character they're working on BEFORE THEY ITERATE. This is usually pretty casual and could be summed up with something like: "Hey, what things stick out to you when you're playing this character?". Playtesters generally get assigned characters that they've played a lot or are within their realm of expertise (I mostly playtest mid or bot lane stuff for example). 
3) Live Gameplay iterates and implements a changelist
4) Playtest reads the list, playtests it, and gives feedback. This step can take a while depending on whether or not we feel we got enough insight from our playtests. Being overconfident based on likely-too-small samples is where our team has made mistakes in the past
5) Live Gameplay decides whether they want to adjust or continue with current list, and the cycle repeats. 

Hopefully that's enough insight to be interesting to you
